definitions.definition: stems of wheat or other grain plants that have been cut and dried. Straw is used for making mats, hats, etc., for packing things to protect them, and as food for animals or for them to sleep on.

examples.text: The rat hid in the straw.

definitions.definition: a single stem or piece of straw

examples.text: He was leaning over the gate chewing on a straw.

definitions.definition: a thin tube of plastic or paper that you drink a liquid through

examples.text: She drank her milkshake through a straw.

definitions.definition: to try all possible means to find a solution or some hope in a difficult or unpleasant situation, even though this seems very unlikely

examples.text: I know I’m just clutching at straws here, but is it possible that the doctors are wrong?

definitions.definition: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task

examples.text: I drew the short straw and had to clean the toilets.

definitions.definition: to use a method of choosing somebody to do or have something in which each person takes a piece of paper, etc. from a container and the one whose paper has a special mark is chosen

examples.text: We drew straws for who went first.

definitions.definition: the last in a series of bad events, etc. that makes it impossible for you to accept a situation any longer
to try to work without the necessary material, money, information, etc.
a small sign of what might happen in the future

wordOrigin: Old English strēaw, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stroo and German Stroh, also to strew.
